newsitem.title: USA: Malcolm Shabazz shows violent tendencies-psychiatrist.
newsitem.headline: Malcolm Shabazz shows violent tendencies-psychiatrist.

text.p: A New York psychiatrist recommended on Tuesday that the 12-year-old grandson of Malcolm X be sent to a secure facility for two or three years because he shows violent tendencies toward himself and others.
Malcolm Shabazz pleaded guilty last week to setting the fire that killed his grandmother, Betty Shabazz.

"He's still struggling with his impulsiveness that could cause violence to himself and others," said Dr. Don Heacock, a psychiatrist at the juvenile detention facility where the boy has been held since his arrest.

Heacock told the judge that he made his "preliminary assessment" based on formal and informal examinations of the boy. He said he still hasn't seen the final probation report that will also include a report from a doctor who is an expert in fire-setting by children.
That report will be discussed at a July 29 hearing.
The psychiatrist said that by "secure," he meant a place where the boy would stay for a period of time, without home visits and without being able to wander around unsupervised.
At the hearing on Tuesday in Family Court in Yonkers, New York, Heacock also said the boy had "severe psychological problems" and needed extensive psychiatric therapy.
Betty Shabazz, 63, died on June 23 from burns she suffered over 80 percent of her body in the June 1 fire. The New York City medical examineer ruled her death a homicide.
Malcolm Shabazz is the son of Qubilah Shabazz, one of six daughters Betty Shabazz had with Malcolm X -- who was assassinated at the Audubon Ballroom in Manhattan on Feb. 21, 1965.
